title: Boy, 8, scratched white lines into his skin after children called him N-word
text:
Finley Sullivan is only 8 but has already been subjected to horrendous racial abuse (Picture: SWNS)

A schoolboy subjected to repeated racist attacks would go days without moisturising his skin so it would ‘go dry and dusty and appear lighter’.

Finlay Sullivan, 8, admitted he would also scratch white lines into his skin in a bid to appear whiter.

He has been repeatedly called the N-word by bullies and said people ‘touch my hair without asking too’.

The abuse has become so bad that his mum Colleen Robinson said when her son goes outside he stares at the floor ‘in fear of being abused’.

Finley, from Par in Cornwall, was born to a Ugandan dad and British mum.

His dad fled the Idi Amin regime and escaped the Ugandan genocide which saw between 500,000 and a million people slaughtered.

At the age 20, with the help of the Red Cross, he was settled in the UK.

Finley is mixed race and has been targeted when out with his white siblings (Picture: SWNS)

Finley said: ‘People say the N-word and that I should go back to Africa where I belong.

‘The first time it happened I was in year one. A kid called me a stupid African and hit me.

‘Sometimes I feel sad and angry. I stopped moisturising so my skin would go dry and dusty and I’d look lighter for school.

‘I scratched white lines into my skin, too, to try and look whiter.

‘People stare at me and touch my hair without asking too.

‘It just makes me feel sad and angry.’

Finley said the racist abuse makes him feel ‘sad and angry’ (Picture: SWNS)

Devastated mum Colleen said the abuse has not been confined to the playground, recalling a recent incident where adult men started making monkey noises at her young son.

She said: ‘I told the kids to keep walking, that the men were making noises because mummy looks silly. Fin said “I know they were making the noises at me because I look like a monkey”.

‘It seems Brexit has given everyone an excuse to bring out their worst side.

‘We want to leave but my husband has a business down here so it isn’t as easy as that.’

One boy, 13, has been prosecuted as a result of racist abuse against Finley, Colleen said.

She added: ‘I’m just sick of people not evolving. It’s like going back in time.’

Colleen wants more black history on the curriculum in Cornish schools in a bid to combat racial intolerance.

His mother wants better education on black history in school so that children are able to learn about diversity (Picture: SWNS)

She said: ‘There’s very little racial diversity here so it’s like you’ve got to hide away and get on with it.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘We’re hoping by speaking out that others who are the victims of racial abuse down here will stand up and know they’re not alone.’

Finley said he hopes to learn the ukulele and one day organise a music festival promoting racial diversity in Cornwall.

He said: ‘I like being mixed race. It’s when people are racist to me I don’t like it, it makes me feel I don’t fit in.’
